security: This document discusses the use of a double agent, DOLPHIN, to gather information on anti-Castro activities. Revealing DOLPHIN's identity or the methods of communication (secret writing) could compromise the agent and disrupt intelligence operations. Specifically, the document states: 'The letterhead memorandum has been classified "SECRET," in order to protect the identity of a double agent of continuing value to the U.S.'
summary: This FBI airtel from March 23, 1967, discusses the use of a Cuban double agent, codenamed DOLPHIN, to gather information on anti-Castro activities in Miami and requests authorization to pass information obtained by DOLPHIN to his Cuban principal.
summary_one_paragraph: An FBI airtel, dated March 23, 1967, from the Director to the SAC in Miami, concerns the operation of a Cuban double agent, codenamed DOLPHIN, tasked with gathering information on anti-Castro activities within the United States. DOLPHIN's principal requested monthly updates on these activities, and the Miami office is instructed to prepare and forward a letter containing the information in secret writing. The memo requests authorization to allow DOLPHIN to provide this information to his Cuban contact by April 7, 1967, and includes details about a meeting of anti-Castro leaders in Miami, including Manuel Fernandez, Manuel Urrutia, and others, who discussed the possibility of a committee traveling to Cuba to discuss the release of political prisoners and potentially improve relations between Cuba and the United States.
title: [Restricted]
